awd_titl_txt: Assessing the Role of Familiarity in Eyewitness Memory and Suggestibility
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Assessing the Role of Familiarity in Eyewitness Memory and Suggestibility

Abstract: 

In legal cases involving child victims of abuse or maltreatment, the person under suspicion often is someone with whom the child is familiar. Yet, most scientific studies on child eyewitness memory examine accuracy and suggestibility concerning briefly-seen strangers. There are important theoretical reasons to indicate that familiarity and relationship factors affect young children's memory and suggestibility. This project will investigate children's abilities to recount accurately their experiences and their willingness to reveal transgressions. 

This project will examine the effects of first-hand person knowledge and socioemotional influences on young children's eye witness reports. Employing an experimental approach, the first study concerns children's memory and suggestibility for an event involving a familiar person versus a stranger. The second study will investigate individual predictors of children's eyewitness memory for a moderately stressful event experienced with their father. For both experiments, assessments of intelligence, mental health, family conflict, and personality will be included to pinpoint significant relations. This research will provide new theoretically driven scientific knowledge about children's eyewitness memory, which in turn will inform the legal system how best to balance protecting children from victimization and protecting adults from false accusations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Child maltreatment is typically committed by perpetrators, such as relatives or neighbors, who are familiar to the children. In the United States, 87% of child maltreatment cases reported to authorities in 2022 by child protective services were committed by parents, relatives, and/or parents’ romantic partners. In many criminal cases of child abuse, over 90% were perpetrated by suspects known to the child. Research on child maltreatment outside of the United States has also revealed a similar predominance of familiar perpetrators (e.g., Taiwan, South Africa, Netherlands, the United Kingdom). Yet most of the child eyewitness accuracy studies to date test children’s memory and suggestibility for briefly seen strangers.

Intellectual merits: In the present research, we examined the effects of familiarity on children's memory and suggestibility. Due to COVID restrictions, we conducted some of our research online. For example, we asked 5- to 10-year-old children to interact with their own fathers and examined relationship and parenting factors. We also examined effects of familiarity on false memory and correlates with a history of maltreatment. Once COVID restrictions were lifted, we were able to randomly assign children to interactions with their own fathers versus male strangers (e.g., other children's fathers) Overall, we found that familiarity in interaction with parenting had a positive effect on children's memory and suggestibility. .

Broader Impacts: Familiarity with fathers was associated with children’s better memory and resistance to suggestion, but parenting also played a role. Our methology and findings apply to the majority of child abuse cases in the US and worldwide. The findings are of interest to attorneys and the courts, as well as to researchers.  


Last Modified: 11/14/2024
Modified by: Gail S Goodman
